articles.title: Eliot Wong-Toi
articles.contents:
Welcome to my website. I hope you enjoy it!
I am a second-year PhD student in statistics at UC Irvine. I previously received a B.S. in Mathematics-Computer Science at UC San Diego in 2019.
My statistical interests lie in computational problems and my personal interests lie in sports; sometimes these two areas overlap.

articles.title: Miscellaneous Projects
articles.contents:
Projects
Fuel Efficiency
Used a linear model to analyze the fuel efficiency of SP98 and E10 fuel. The data came from a single driver’s personal log of trips in a single vehicle over the course of a year.

Coronavirus Reproduction Number
Class project with Isaac Goldstein estimating the reproduction number for coronavirus in Hubei province fit to data from early 2020. We applied the technique of linear noise approximation to data from early 2020 and fit a susceptible-infectious-recovered (SIR) model.

articles.title: Research
articles.description: Some more about my research experience and interests.
articles.contents:
UC Irvine
Sports Analytics
Analyzing NBA shot chart data with Professor Weining Shen and Professor Guangyu Hu to cluster players based on offensive contributions. This project is just starting.

Micro-Randomized Trials with Binary Outcomes
Co-writing mrtbincalc package and Shiny app for power and sample size calculations in the context of micro-randomized trials with binary outcomes with Thabat Dahdoul under the direction of Professor Tianchen Qian. Both are currently under development. mrtbincalc will later be posted on CRAN and the Shiny app will be deployed soon as well. The formula that is implemented in this package and shiny app is developed in “Sample Size Considerations for Micro-Randomized Trials with Binary Outcome” which is currently a work in progress.

Radiomics
Worked with Professor Michele Guindani in collaboration with UC Davis scientists to analyze radiomic data for predicting skin cancer. Used Bayesian methods to perform variable selection and fit logistic regression models to provide quantitative evidence for examining certain traits in imaging data.

UC San Diego
Medical Imaging
Implemented convolutional neural network for lung segmentation in MRI images in the UCSD Pulmonary Imaging Lab under the supervision of Professor Rui Carlos Pereira de Sa. This tool was to be put in the post-processing pipeline and alleviate the burden of hand-tagging thousands of MRI images per subject.
